trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting DSC222
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting DSC222

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0

trans-unit.source: This topic describes methods for getting your Desired State Configuration (DSC) scripts to run without error.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes methods for getting your Desired State Configuration (DSC) scripts to run without error.

trans-unit.source: By using logs effectively to track down errors, and understanding how to recycle the cache to see the immediate results of your resource changes, you’ll be able to troubleshoot DSC more effectively.
trans-unit.target: By using logs effectively to track down errors, and understanding how to recycle the cache to see the immediate results of your resource changes, you’ll be able to troubleshoot DSC more effectively.

trans-unit.source: These technics are discussed in two sections:
trans-unit.target: These technics are discussed in two sections:

trans-unit.source: My script won’t run: **Using DSC logs to diagnose script errors**
trans-unit.target: My script won’t run: **Using DSC logs to diagnose script errors**

trans-unit.source: My resources won’t update: **How to reset the cache**
trans-unit.target: My resources won’t update: **How to reset the cache**

trans-unit.source: My script won’t run: Using DSC logs to diagnose script errors
trans-unit.target: My script won’t run: Using DSC logs to diagnose script errors

trans-unit.source: Like all Windows software, DSC records errors and events in [logs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363632.aspx) that can be viewed from the [Event Viewer](http://windows.microsoft.com/windows/what-information-event-logs-event-viewer).
trans-unit.target: Like all Windows software, DSC records errors and events in [logs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363632.aspx) that can be viewed from the [Event Viewer](http://windows.microsoft.com/windows/what-information-event-logs-event-viewer).

trans-unit.source: Examining these logs can help you understand why a particular operation failed, and how to prevent failure in the future.
trans-unit.target: Examining these logs can help you understand why a particular operation failed, and how to prevent failure in the future.

trans-unit.source: Writing configuration scripts can be tricky, so to make tracking errors easier as you author, use the DSC Log resource to track the progress of your configuration in the DSC Analytic event log.
trans-unit.target: Writing configuration scripts can be tricky, so to make tracking errors easier as you author, use the DSC Log resource to track the progress of your configuration in the DSC Analytic event log.

trans-unit.source: Where are DSC event logs?
trans-unit.target: Where are DSC event logs?

trans-unit.source: In Event Viewer, DSC events are in: **Applications and Services Logs/Microsoft/Windows/Desired State Configuration**
trans-unit.target: In Event Viewer, DSC events are in: **Applications and Services Logs/Microsoft/Windows/Desired State Configuration**

trans-unit.source: The corresponding PowerShell cmdlet, [Get-WinEvent](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849682.aspx), can also be run to view the event logs:
trans-unit.target: The corresponding PowerShell cmdlet, [Get-WinEvent](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849682.aspx), can also be run to view the event logs:

trans-unit.source: As shown above, DSC’s primary log name is **Microsoft->Windows->DSC** (other log names under Windows are not shown here for brevity).
trans-unit.target: As shown above, DSC’s primary log name is **Microsoft->Windows->DSC** (other log names under Windows are not shown here for brevity).

trans-unit.source: The primary name is appended to the channel name to create the complete log name.
trans-unit.target: The primary name is appended to the channel name to create the complete log name.

trans-unit.source: The DSC engine writes mainly into three types of logs: [Operational, Analytic, and Debug logs](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc722404.aspx).
trans-unit.target: The DSC engine writes mainly into three types of logs: [Operational, Analytic, and Debug logs](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc722404.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Since the analytic and debug logs are turned off by default, you should enable them in Event Viewer.
trans-unit.target: Since the analytic and debug logs are turned off by default, you should enable them in Event Viewer.

trans-unit.source: To do this, open Event Viewer by typing eventvwr in Windows PowerShell; or, click the **Start** button, click **Control Panel**, click **Administrative Tools**, and then click **Event Viewer**.
trans-unit.target: To do this, open Event Viewer by typing eventvwr in Windows PowerShell; or, click the **Start** button, click **Control Panel**, click **Administrative Tools**, and then click **Event Viewer**.

trans-unit.source: On the **View** menu in Event viewer, click **Show Analytic and Debug Logs**.
trans-unit.target: On the **View** menu in Event viewer, click **Show Analytic and Debug Logs**.

trans-unit.source: The log name for the analytic channel is **Microsoft-Windows-Dsc/Analytic**, and the debug channel is **Microsoft-Windows-Dsc/Debug**.
trans-unit.target: The log name for the analytic channel is **Microsoft-Windows-Dsc/Analytic**, and the debug channel is **Microsoft-Windows-Dsc/Debug**.

trans-unit.source: You could also use the [wevtutil](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc732848.aspx) utility to enable the logs, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: You could also use the [wevtutil](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc732848.aspx) utility to enable the logs, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: What do DSC logs contain?
trans-unit.target: What do DSC logs contain?

trans-unit.source: DSC logs are split over the three log channels based on the importance of the message.
trans-unit.target: DSC logs are split over the three log channels based on the importance of the message.

trans-unit.source: The operational log in DSC contains all error messages, and can be used to identify a problem.
trans-unit.target: The operational log in DSC contains all error messages, and can be used to identify a problem.

trans-unit.source: The analytic log has a higher volume of events, and can identify where error(s) occurred.
trans-unit.target: The analytic log has a higher volume of events, and can identify where error(s) occurred.

trans-unit.source: This channel also contains verbose messages (if any).
trans-unit.target: This channel also contains verbose messages (if any).

trans-unit.source: The debug log contains logs that can help you understand how the errors occurred.
trans-unit.target: The debug log contains logs that can help you understand how the errors occurred.

trans-unit.source: DSC event messages are structured such that every event message begins with a job ID that uniquely represents a DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: DSC event messages are structured such that every event message begins with a job ID that uniquely represents a DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: The example below attempts to obtain the message from the first event logged into the operational DSC log.
trans-unit.target: The example below attempts to obtain the message from the first event logged into the operational DSC log.

trans-unit.source: DSC events are logged in a particular structure that enables the user to aggregate events from one DSC job.
trans-unit.target: DSC events are logged in a particular structure that enables the user to aggregate events from one DSC job.

trans-unit.source: The structure is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The structure is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Job ID : \<Guid\>
trans-unit.target: Job ID : \<Guid\>

trans-unit.source: \<Event Message\>
trans-unit.target: \<Event Message\>

trans-unit.source: Gathering events from a single DSC operation
trans-unit.target: Gathering events from a single DSC operation

trans-unit.source: DSC event logs contain events generated by various DSC operations.
trans-unit.target: DSC event logs contain events generated by various DSC operations.

trans-unit.source: However, you’ll usually be concerned with the detail about just one particular operation.
trans-unit.target: However, you’ll usually be concerned with the detail about just one particular operation.

trans-unit.source: All DSC logs can be grouped by the job ID property that is unique for every DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: All DSC logs can be grouped by the job ID property that is unique for every DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: The job ID is displayed as the first property value in all DSC events.
trans-unit.target: The job ID is displayed as the first property value in all DSC events.

trans-unit.source: The following steps explain how to accumulate all events in a grouped array structure.
trans-unit.target: The following steps explain how to accumulate all events in a grouped array structure.

trans-unit.source: Here, the variable `$SeparateDscOperations` contains logs grouped by the job IDs.
trans-unit.target: Here, the variable `$SeparateDscOperations` contains logs grouped by the job IDs.

trans-unit.source: Each array element of this variable represents a group of events logged by a different DSC operation, allowing access to more information about the logs.
trans-unit.target: Each array element of this variable represents a group of events logged by a different DSC operation, allowing access to more information about the logs.

trans-unit.source: You can extract the data in the variable `$SeparateDscOperations` using [Where-Object](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee177028.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can extract the data in the variable `$SeparateDscOperations` using [Where-Object](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee177028.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Following are five scenarios in which you might want to extract data for troubleshooting DSC:
trans-unit.target: Following are five scenarios in which you might want to extract data for troubleshooting DSC:

trans-unit.source: 1: Operations failures
trans-unit.target: 1: Operations failures

trans-unit.source: All events have [severity levels](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dd996917(v=vs.85)).
trans-unit.target: All events have [severity levels](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dd996917(v=vs.85)).

trans-unit.source: This information can be used to identify the error events:
trans-unit.target: This information can be used to identify the error events:

trans-unit.source: 2: Details of operations run in the last half hour
trans-unit.target: 2: Details of operations run in the last half hour

trans-unit.source: `TimeCreated`, a property of every Windows event, states the time the event was created.
trans-unit.target: `TimeCreated`, a property of every Windows event, states the time the event was created.

trans-unit.source: Comparing this property with a particular date/time object can be used to filter all events:
trans-unit.target: Comparing this property with a particular date/time object can be used to filter all events:

trans-unit.source: 3: Messages from the latest operation
trans-unit.target: 3: Messages from the latest operation

trans-unit.source: The latest operation is stored in the first index of the array group `$SeparateDscOperations`.
trans-unit.target: The latest operation is stored in the first index of the array group `$SeparateDscOperations`.

trans-unit.source: Querying the group’s messages for index 0 returns all messages for the latest operation:
trans-unit.target: Querying the group’s messages for index 0 returns all messages for the latest operation:

trans-unit.source: 4: Error messages logged for recent failed operations
trans-unit.target: 4: Error messages logged for recent failed operations

trans-unit.source: `$SeparateDscOperations[0].Group` contains a set of events for the latest operation.
trans-unit.target: `$SeparateDscOperations[0].Group` contains a set of events for the latest operation.

trans-unit.source: Run the `Where-Object` cmdlet to filter the events based on their level display name.
trans-unit.target: Run the `Where-Object` cmdlet to filter the events based on their level display name.

trans-unit.source: Results are stored in the `$myFailedEvent` variable, which can be further dissected to get the event message:
trans-unit.target: Results are stored in the `$myFailedEvent` variable, which can be further dissected to get the event message:

trans-unit.source: 5: All events generated for a particular job ID.
trans-unit.target: 5: All events generated for a particular job ID.

trans-unit.source: `$SeparateDscOperations` is an array of groups, each of which has the name as the unique job ID.
trans-unit.target: `$SeparateDscOperations` is an array of groups, each of which has the name as the unique job ID.

trans-unit.source: By running the `Where-Object` cmdlet, you can extract those groups of events that have a particular job ID:
trans-unit.target: By running the `Where-Object` cmdlet, you can extract those groups of events that have a particular job ID:

trans-unit.source: Using xDscDiagnostics to analyze DSC logs
trans-unit.target: Using xDscDiagnostics to analyze DSC logs

trans-unit.source: **xDscDiagnostics** is a PowerShell module that consists of two simple operations that can help analyze DSC failures on your machine: `Get-xDscOperation` and `Trace-xDscOperation`.
trans-unit.target: **xDscDiagnostics** is a PowerShell module that consists of two simple operations that can help analyze DSC failures on your machine: `Get-xDscOperation` and `Trace-xDscOperation`.

trans-unit.source: These functions can help you identify all local events from past DSC operations, or DSC events on remote computers (with valid credentials).
trans-unit.target: These functions can help you identify all local events from past DSC operations, or DSC events on remote computers (with valid credentials).

trans-unit.source: Here, the term DSC Operation is used to define a single unique DSC execution from its start to its end.
trans-unit.target: Here, the term DSC Operation is used to define a single unique DSC execution from its start to its end.

trans-unit.source: For example, `Test-DscConfiguration` would be a separate DSC Operation.
trans-unit.target: For example, `Test-DscConfiguration` would be a separate DSC Operation.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, every other cmdlet in DSC (such as `Get-DscConfiguration`, `Start-DscConfiguration`, etc.) could each be identified as separate DSC operations.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, every other cmdlet in DSC (such as `Get-DscConfiguration`, `Start-DscConfiguration`, etc.) could each be identified as separate DSC operations.

trans-unit.source: The two cmdlets are explained in [xDscDiagnostics](https://powershellgallery.com/packages/xDscDiagnostics) PowerShell Module (DSC Resource Kit) and in more detail below.
trans-unit.target: The two cmdlets are explained in [xDscDiagnostics](https://powershellgallery.com/packages/xDscDiagnostics) PowerShell Module (DSC Resource Kit) and in more detail below.

trans-unit.source: Help is available by running `Get-Help <cmdlet name>`.
trans-unit.target: Help is available by running `Get-Help <cmdlet name>`.

trans-unit.source: Get-xDscOperation
trans-unit.target: Get-xDscOperation

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet lets you find the results of the DSC operations that run on one or multiple computers, and returns an object that contains the collection of events produced by each DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet lets you find the results of the DSC operations that run on one or multiple computers, and returns an object that contains the collection of events produced by each DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the following output, three commands were run.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the following output, three commands were run.

trans-unit.source: The first one passed, and the other two failed.
trans-unit.target: The first one passed, and the other two failed.

trans-unit.source: These results are summarized in the output of `Get-xDscOperation`.
trans-unit.target: These results are summarized in the output of `Get-xDscOperation`.

trans-unit.source: TODO: Replace this image that shows Get-xDscOperation output
trans-unit.target: TODO: Replace this image that shows Get-xDscOperation output

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: **Newest**: Accepts an integer value to indicate the number of operations to be displayed.
trans-unit.target: **Newest**: Accepts an integer value to indicate the number of operations to be displayed.

trans-unit.source: By default, it returns 10 newest operations.
trans-unit.target: By default, it returns 10 newest operations.

trans-unit.source: For instance,
trans-unit.target: For instance,

trans-unit.source: TODO: Show Get-xDscOperation -Newest 5
trans-unit.target: TODO: Show Get-xDscOperation -Newest 5

trans-unit.source: **ComputerName**: Parameter that accepts an array of strings, each containing the name of a computer from where you’d like to collect DSC event log data.
trans-unit.target: **ComputerName**: Parameter that accepts an array of strings, each containing the name of a computer from where you’d like to collect DSC event log data.

trans-unit.source: By default, it collects data from the host machine.
trans-unit.target: By default, it collects data from the host machine.

trans-unit.source: To enable this feature, you must run the following command in the remote machines, in elevated mode so that the will allow collection of events
trans-unit.target: To enable this feature, you must run the following command in the remote machines, in elevated mode so that the will allow collection of events

trans-unit.source: **Credential**: Parameter that is of type PSCredential, which can help access to the computers specified in the ComputerName parameter.
trans-unit.target: **Credential**: Parameter that is of type PSCredential, which can help access to the computers specified in the ComputerName parameter.

trans-unit.source: Returned object
trans-unit.target: Returned object

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet returns an array of objects each of type **Microsoft.PowerShell.xDscDiagnostics.GroupedEvents**.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet returns an array of objects each of type **Microsoft.PowerShell.xDscDiagnostics.GroupedEvents**.

trans-unit.source: Each object in this array pertains to a different DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: Each object in this array pertains to a different DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: The default display for this object has the following properties
trans-unit.target: The default display for this object has the following properties

trans-unit.source: **SequenceID**: Specifies the incremental number assigned to the DSC operation based on time.
trans-unit.target: **SequenceID**: Specifies the incremental number assigned to the DSC operation based on time.

trans-unit.source: For example, the last executed operation would have SequenceID as 1, the second to last DSC operation would have SequenceID of 2, and so on.
trans-unit.target: For example, the last executed operation would have SequenceID as 1, the second to last DSC operation would have SequenceID of 2, and so on.

trans-unit.source: This number is another identifier for each object in the returned array.
trans-unit.target: This number is another identifier for each object in the returned array.

trans-unit.source: **TimeCreated**: A DateTime value that indicates when the DSC operation began.
trans-unit.target: **TimeCreated**: A DateTime value that indicates when the DSC operation began.

trans-unit.source: **ComputerName**: The computer name from where the results are aggregated.
trans-unit.target: **ComputerName**: The computer name from where the results are aggregated.

trans-unit.source: **Result**: A string with value **Failure** or **Success** that indicates if that DSC operation had an error or not, respectively.
trans-unit.target: **Result**: A string with value **Failure** or **Success** that indicates if that DSC operation had an error or not, respectively.

trans-unit.source: **AllEvents**: An object that represents a collection of events produced by the DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: **AllEvents**: An object that represents a collection of events produced by the DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following output shows results of the last operation from multiple computers:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following output shows results of the last operation from multiple computers:

trans-unit.source: TODO: Replace picture for Get-xDscOperation to display remote computer logs
trans-unit.target: TODO: Replace picture for Get-xDscOperation to display remote computer logs

trans-unit.source: Trace-xDscOperation
trans-unit.target: Trace-xDscOperation

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet returns an object containing a collection of events, their event types, and the message output generated from a particular DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet returns an object containing a collection of events, their event types, and the message output generated from a particular DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: Typically, when you find a failure in any of the operations using `Get-xDscOperation`, you would trace that operation to find out which of the events caused a failure.
trans-unit.target: Typically, when you find a failure in any of the operations using `Get-xDscOperation`, you would trace that operation to find out which of the events caused a failure.

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: **SequenceID**: This is the integer value assigned to any operation, pertaining to a specific computer.
trans-unit.target: **SequenceID**: This is the integer value assigned to any operation, pertaining to a specific computer.

trans-unit.source: By specifying a sequence ID of say, 4, the trace for the DSC operation that was 4th from the last will be output
trans-unit.target: By specifying a sequence ID of say, 4, the trace for the DSC operation that was 4th from the last will be output

trans-unit.source: Trace-xDscOperation with sequence ID specified
trans-unit.target: Trace-xDscOperation with sequence ID specified

trans-unit.source: **JobID**: This is the GUID value assigned by LCM xDscOperation to uniquely identify an operation.
trans-unit.target: **JobID**: This is the GUID value assigned by LCM xDscOperation to uniquely identify an operation.

trans-unit.source: when a JobID is specified, the trace of the corresponding DSC operation is output.
trans-unit.target: when a JobID is specified, the trace of the corresponding DSC operation is output.

trans-unit.source: TODO: Replace picture for Trace-xDscOperation taking JobID as a parameter
trans-unit.target: TODO: Replace picture for Trace-xDscOperation taking JobID as a parameter

trans-unit.source: **ComputerName** and **Credential**: These parameters allow the trace to be collected from remote computers:
trans-unit.target: **ComputerName** and **Credential**: These parameters allow the trace to be collected from remote computers:

trans-unit.source: TODO: Replace picture for Trace-xDscOperation run on a different compute
trans-unit.target: TODO: Replace picture for Trace-xDscOperation run on a different compute

trans-unit.source: Note that, since `Trace-xDscOperation` aggregates events from the Analytic, Debug, and operational logs, it will prompt you to enable these logs as described above.
trans-unit.target: Note that, since `Trace-xDscOperation` aggregates events from the Analytic, Debug, and operational logs, it will prompt you to enable these logs as described above.

trans-unit.source: Returned object
trans-unit.target: Returned object

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet returns an array of objects, each of type `Microsoft.PowerShell.xDscDiagnostics.TraceOutput`.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet returns an array of objects, each of type `Microsoft.PowerShell.xDscDiagnostics.TraceOutput`.

trans-unit.source: Each object in this array contains the following fields:
trans-unit.target: Each object in this array contains the following fields:

trans-unit.source: **ComputerName**: The name of the computer from where the logs are being collected.
trans-unit.target: **ComputerName**: The name of the computer from where the logs are being collected.

trans-unit.source: **EventType**: This is an enumerator type field that contains information on the type of event.
trans-unit.target: **EventType**: This is an enumerator type field that contains information on the type of event.

trans-unit.source: It could be any of the following:
trans-unit.target: It could be any of the following:

trans-unit.source: *Operational*: The event is from the operational log.
trans-unit.target: *Operational*: The event is from the operational log.

trans-unit.source: *Analytic*: The event is from the analytic log.
trans-unit.target: *Analytic*: The event is from the analytic log.

trans-unit.source: *Debug*: The event is from the debug log.
trans-unit.target: *Debug*: The event is from the debug log.

trans-unit.source: *Verbose*: Events output as verbose messages during execution.
trans-unit.target: *Verbose*: Events output as verbose messages during execution.

trans-unit.source: The verbose messages make it easy to identify the sequence of events that are published.
trans-unit.target: The verbose messages make it easy to identify the sequence of events that are published.

trans-unit.source: *Error*: Error events.
trans-unit.target: *Error*: Error events.

trans-unit.source: By looking for the error events, you can usually quickly find the reason for the failure.
trans-unit.target: By looking for the error events, you can usually quickly find the reason for the failure.

trans-unit.source: **TimeCreated**: A DateTime value indicating when the event was logged by DSC.
trans-unit.target: **TimeCreated**: A DateTime value indicating when the event was logged by DSC.

trans-unit.source: **Message**: The message that was logged by DSC into the event logs.
trans-unit.target: **Message**: The message that was logged by DSC into the event logs.

trans-unit.source: Following are fields in this object that can be used for more information about the event, but are not displayed by default:
trans-unit.target: Following are fields in this object that can be used for more information about the event, but are not displayed by default:

trans-unit.source: **JobID**: The job ID (GUID format) specific to that DSC operation.
trans-unit.target: **JobID**: The job ID (GUID format) specific to that DSC operation.

trans-unit.source: **SequenceID**: The SequenceID unique to that DSC operation in that computer.
trans-unit.target: **SequenceID**: The SequenceID unique to that DSC operation in that computer.

trans-unit.source: **Event**: This is the actual event logged by DSC, of type `System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord`.
trans-unit.target: **Event**: This is the actual event logged by DSC, of type `System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord`.

trans-unit.source: This can also the obtained by running the cmdlet `Get-WinEvent`.
trans-unit.target: This can also the obtained by running the cmdlet `Get-WinEvent`.

trans-unit.source: It contains more information, such as the task, eventID, and level of the event.
trans-unit.target: It contains more information, such as the task, eventID, and level of the event.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, you can gather information on the events by saving the output of `Trace-xDscOperation` into a variable.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, you can gather information on the events by saving the output of `Trace-xDscOperation` into a variable.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following command to display all the events for a particular DSC operation:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following command to display all the events for a particular DSC operation:

trans-unit.source: This will display the same results as the `Get-WinEvent` cmdlet, such as in the output below:
trans-unit.target: This will display the same results as the `Get-WinEvent` cmdlet, such as in the output below:

trans-unit.source: TODO: What output?
trans-unit.target: TODO: What output?

trans-unit.source: Ideally, you would first use `Get-xDscOperations` to list out the last few DSC configuration runs on your machines.
trans-unit.target: Ideally, you would first use `Get-xDscOperations` to list out the last few DSC configuration runs on your machines.

trans-unit.source: Following this, you can examine any single operation (using its sequenceID or JobID) with `Trace-xDscOperation` to discover what it did behind the scenes.
trans-unit.target: Following this, you can examine any single operation (using its sequenceID or JobID) with `Trace-xDscOperation` to discover what it did behind the scenes.

trans-unit.source: My resources won’t update: How to reset the cache
trans-unit.target: My resources won’t update: How to reset the cache

trans-unit.source: The DSC engine caches resources implemented as a PowerShell module for efficiency purposes.
trans-unit.target: The DSC engine caches resources implemented as a PowerShell module for efficiency purposes.

trans-unit.source: However, this can cause problems when you are authoring a resource and testing it simultaneously because DSC will load the cached version until the process is restarted.
trans-unit.target: However, this can cause problems when you are authoring a resource and testing it simultaneously because DSC will load the cached version until the process is restarted.

trans-unit.source: The only way to make DSC load the newer version is to explicitly kill the process hosting the DSC engine.
trans-unit.target: The only way to make DSC load the newer version is to explicitly kill the process hosting the DSC engine.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, when you run `Start-DSCConfiguration`, after adding and modifying a custom resource, the modification may not execute unless, or until, the computer is rebooted.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, when you run `Start-DSCConfiguration`, after adding and modifying a custom resource, the modification may not execute unless, or until, the computer is rebooted.

trans-unit.source: This is because DSC runs in the WMI Provider Host Process (WmiPrvSE), and usually, there are many instances of WmiPrvSE running at once.
trans-unit.target: This is because DSC runs in the WMI Provider Host Process (WmiPrvSE), and usually, there are many instances of WmiPrvSE running at once.

trans-unit.source: When you reboot, the host process is restarted and the cache is cleared.
trans-unit.target: When you reboot, the host process is restarted and the cache is cleared.

trans-unit.source: To successfully recycle the configuration and clear the cache without rebooting, you must stop and then restart the host process.
trans-unit.target: To successfully recycle the configuration and clear the cache without rebooting, you must stop and then restart the host process.

trans-unit.source: This can be done on a per instance basis, whereby you identify the process, stop it, and restart it.
trans-unit.target: This can be done on a per instance basis, whereby you identify the process, stop it, and restart it.

trans-unit.source: Or, you can use `DebugMode`, as demonstrated below, to reload the PowerShell DSC resource.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can use `DebugMode`, as demonstrated below, to reload the PowerShell DSC resource.

trans-unit.source: To identify which process is hosting the DSC engine and stop it on a per instance basis, you can list the process ID of the WmiPrvSE which is hosting the DSC engine.
trans-unit.target: To identify which process is hosting the DSC engine and stop it on a per instance basis, you can list the process ID of the WmiPrvSE which is hosting the DSC engine.

trans-unit.source: Then, to update the provider, stop the WmiPrvSE process using the commands below, and then run **Start-DscConfiguration** again.
trans-unit.target: Then, to update the provider, stop the WmiPrvSE process using the commands below, and then run **Start-DscConfiguration** again.

trans-unit.source: Using DebugMode
trans-unit.target: Using DebugMode

trans-unit.source: You can configure the DSC Local Configuration Manager (LCM) to use `DebugMode` to always clear the cache when the host process is restarted.
trans-unit.target: You can configure the DSC Local Configuration Manager (LCM) to use `DebugMode` to always clear the cache when the host process is restarted.

trans-unit.source: When set to **TRUE**, it causes the engine to always reload the PowerShell DSC resource.
trans-unit.target: When set to **TRUE**, it causes the engine to always reload the PowerShell DSC resource.

trans-unit.source: Once you are done writing your resource, you can set it back to **FALSE** and the engine will revert to its behavior of caching the modules.
trans-unit.target: Once you are done writing your resource, you can set it back to **FALSE** and the engine will revert to its behavior of caching the modules.

trans-unit.source: Following is a demonstration to show how `DebugMode` can automatically refresh the cache.
trans-unit.target: Following is a demonstration to show how `DebugMode` can automatically refresh the cache.

trans-unit.source: First, let’s look at the default configuration:
trans-unit.target: First, let’s look at the default configuration:

trans-unit.source: You can see that `DebugMode` is set to **FALSE**.
trans-unit.target: You can see that `DebugMode` is set to **FALSE**.

trans-unit.source: To set up the `DebugMode` demonstration, use the following PowerShell resource:
trans-unit.target: To set up the `DebugMode` demonstration, use the following PowerShell resource:

trans-unit.source: Now, author a configuration using the above resource called `TestProviderDebugMode`:
trans-unit.target: Now, author a configuration using the above resource called `TestProviderDebugMode`:

trans-unit.source: You will see that the contents of file: “**$env:SystemDrive\OutputFromTestProviderDebugMode.txt**” is **1**.
trans-unit.target: You will see that the contents of file: “**$env:SystemDrive\OutputFromTestProviderDebugMode.txt**” is **1**.

trans-unit.source: Now, update the provider code using the following script:
trans-unit.target: Now, update the provider code using the following script:

trans-unit.source: This script generates a random number and updates the provider cade accordingly.
trans-unit.target: This script generates a random number and updates the provider cade accordingly.

trans-unit.source: With `DebugMode` set to false, the contents of the file “**$env:SystemDrive\OutputFromTestProviderDebugMode.txt**” are never changed.
trans-unit.target: With `DebugMode` set to false, the contents of the file “**$env:SystemDrive\OutputFromTestProviderDebugMode.txt**” are never changed.

trans-unit.source: Now, set `DebugMode` to **TRUE** in your configuration script:
trans-unit.target: Now, set `DebugMode` to **TRUE** in your configuration script:

trans-unit.source: When you run the above script again, you will see that the content of the file is different every time.
trans-unit.target: When you run the above script again, you will see that the content of the file is different every time.

trans-unit.source: (You can run `Get-DscConfiguration` to check it).
trans-unit.target: (You can run `Get-DscConfiguration` to check it).
